posts.name: Mat Robotics
posts.cooked:
hex-holder 2880×1502 336 KB

hex-holder 2880×1502 336 KB

hex-holder 2880×1502 336 KB

Hi everyone,

We’d like to share a simple but highly effective 3D printable part we’ve designed: the Half Inch Hex Shaft Holder. This component was developed for teams looking for a lightweight, durable, and low-cost shaft retention solution – especially during prototyping or quick fixes in the pits.

Features :

Low Cost : Designed to be budget-friendly and accessible.

Durability : PETG or Nylon prints provide long-lasting performance under stress.

Light Weight : Helps reduce overall weight on subsystems without compromising strength.

Instructions for Use :

To ensure optimal performance:

Filament : Use PETG or Nylon

Walls : 3 perimeters

Infill : % 25

After printing :

Insert an M4 nut into the provided nut slot.

Pass an M4 screw through the hole on the opposite side.

Slide your 1/2" hex shaft into place and tighten the screw to secure.

We’ve used this part successfully on several prototypes and recommend it for teams in need of a fast, reliable solution.

Download the model here

We’d love to hear your feedback, and feel free to remix or improve it !

— Team 6228 | MAT Robotics

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Am I the only who accidentally read that as 6328 at first?

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: Do you have a picture of it being used?

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: So is this like a lower-cost, lightweight alternative to a shaft collar?

posts.name: Mat Robotics
posts.cooked: Yes, it is a cheaper alternative to a shaft collar . we had to use this because of the strict import rules of our country.
I bet if you printed this out of TPU, you could probably slip it onto an axle without having to slide it on the end (which may require disassembly).  Cool!

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked: How much clamping force can this actually provide before it starts to fracture?

posts.name: Josh Sirota
posts.cooked:
Sam948:

Am I the only who accidentally read that as 6328 at first?

Tell me about it.

In my experience, 3dp shaft collars can’t take high loads (especially localized loads which are common on shafts) and wouldn’t suggest them for anything more than indexers completely inside the frame perimeter or deadaxles with no side loads. Plastic being about 100 times less stiff than steel means you can’t apply any real preload on the screw, which means you can’t generate very much clamping force.

Hex shaft is even more problematic because the sharp corners start cracks which lead to failure under normal usage, which is just a reliability issue waiting to happen on a robot. CFny can be somewhat resistant to fracture, but PLA and PETG don’t have a high fracture toughness which leads to premature failure from stress risers.
